channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Coller Capital Bundles Private Equity Stakes in $1 Billion Securitization
item.description: Coller Capital is assembling a roughly $1 billion structured finance instrument backed by stakes in some of its private capital secondary funds, the firm’s second such deal this year, according to people with knowledge of the transaction.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

item.title: SQM Feeds Global Lithium Glut With Record-High Sales Volume
item.description: SQM sold record amounts of lithium in the first quarter, despite prices languishing at multiyear lows as one of the world’s top producers of the battery metal counts on low costs to grow market share.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood, Annie Lee

item.title: UK’s Nissan Backing Shows Starmer’s Push to Save Industrial Jobs
item.description: The prospect of new support from the UK government for Nissan Motor Co. is the latest sign of Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s push to protect Britain’s industrial base as he tries to stave off a political threat from Nigel Farage’s Reform party and preserve the Japanese automaker’s famous Sunderland plant.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Jamie Nimmo

media:content.media:description: The Nissan production plant in Sunderland, England.

item.title: Gold Fluctuates With US Data and Trade Talks in Focus
item.description: Gold wavered after a two-day decline as the market remained in wait-and-see mode in spite of data showing improving economic sentiment and signs of progress in trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: A gold bar, part of the Czech National Bank's reserves arranged in Prague, Czech Republic, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Gold’s recent record-breaking run has been broadly supported by haven demand, amid concern and increasing confusion over US President Donald Trump’s plan to enact sweeping tariffs.

item.title: Oil Rises as Traders Weigh Risks to Iranian, Russian Supplies
item.description: Oil climbed as the market assessed the risk of additional US sanctions on Russia and the chance that nuclear talks with Iran will fail to produce an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: A storage tank at an oil refinery operated by Bharat Petroleum Corp. Ltd., in Mumbai, India, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Indian refiners have rushed back to the market to seek crude supply after President Donald Trump’s threat of more penalties against Russia raised concerns over potential disruptions to oil flows. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Stocks Fall Before Nvidia’s Results as Yields Rise: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street halted its rebound just hours ahead of the highly anticipated results from Nvidia Corp. — the last of the “Magnificent Seven” megacaps to report.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

item.title: US Banks’ Paper Losses Eased as Net Income Rose, FDIC Says
item.description: US banks’ paper losses eased in the first quarter, while net income increased, according to a report published Wednesday by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Buildings in the Manhattan skyline in New York, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. New York City officials cut their forecast for the number of international tourists this year by 17%, saying President Donald Trumps tariffs and hard-line policies on immigration are deterring visitors. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

item.title: Bridgepoint in Talks to Sell French Broker Kereis to Advent
item.description: Bridgepoint Group Plc is in talks to sell French broker Kereis to buyout firm Advent, adding to a wave of insurance deals in Europe as the industry consolidates.
item.dc:creator: Ruth David, Swetha Gopinath, Dinesh Nair

media:content.media:description: Buildings on the city skyline beside the River Seine in Paris, France, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. After the Olympics, Air France — which is one of the event sponsors — expects travel to and from Paris to return to normal, with the summer games likely to spark renewed interest in the destination, it said. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Germany Sees High Bar for Gas Storage Intervention If Goals Missed
item.description: Germany sees a high bar for any intervention to support gas storage efforts this year, even if the country ends up missing its new legally-binding targets.
item.dc:creator: Petra Sorge

media:content.media:description: An oil tanker truck departs an oil terminal in the Port of Hamburg in Hamburg, Germany.

item.title: US Stocks Decline Ahead of Nvidia’s First-Quarter Earnings
item.description: US stocks traded lower on Wednesday ahead of highly anticipated earnings from Nvidia Corp.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: 'Perfect Storm' of Events Leading to Weak Japan Sale: Kochugovindan
item.description: Aberdeen Senior Research Economist Sree Kochugovindan discusses the weak Japan 40-year bond sale and broader concerns of deficits with Bloomberg's Guy Johnson, Anna Edwards and Kriti Gupta on "The Opening Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Carney’s Defense Spending Will Add Up to $46 Billion to Economy, CIBC Says
item.description: The economic gains of Prime Minister Mark Carney’s defense spending boost will likely be worth more than double the planned investment costs, according to Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce economists.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: A Canadian flag on the sleeve of a member of the Canadian Armed Forces at the Decarie Square Covid-19 vaccination site in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Wednesday, Jan. 12, 2022. Members of the armed services have been deployed in the province since January 3 to help with third dose vaccination efforts as hospitalizations rise.

item.title: Weinstein on the Hedge Fund Talent War, Harvard
item.description: Ilana Weinstein, CEO and founder of IDW Group, talks about the talent war for hedge funds, how market volatility is affecting returns and how the Trump administration's battle with Harvard could be impacting the talent pool. She is on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: India Bans Former IndusInd CEO, Others in Insider Trading Case
item.description: India’s securities market regulator has banned some former as well current top executives of IndusInd Bank Ltd., backed by the billionaire Hinduja brothers, from accessing the capital markets in a case of alleged insider trading, according to an initial order.
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

media:content.media:description: An IndusInd Bank branch in New Delhi.

item.title: See Chinese Tech as Undervalued: Guild
item.description: Robinhood CIO Stephanie Guild discusses the upcoming July and August tariff dates, portfolio diversification for US investors and opportunities in Chinese tech with Bloomberg's Dani Burger on "Bloomberg Brief." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: OPEC+ Ratifies Group-Wide Quotas Before July Output Decision
item.description: OPEC+ ratified group-wide production quotas for this year and next, ahead of a decision by eight key members at the weekend whether to bolster output again in July.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith, Fiona MacDonald, Salma El Wardany, Nayla Razzouk

item.title: Close to 'Inflection Point' for Yields: BNP Paribas’ Robson
item.description: Meghan Robson, Head of US Credit Strategy at BNP Paribas, says we are close to an inflection point where higher yields can start to challenge credit. She speaks to Bloomberg's Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Companies in "Wait-and-Watch" Period: Adams
item.description: Marissa Adams, HSBC Regional Head of Global Trade Solutions for Europe and Americas, discusses the results of HSBC's latest trade pulse survey with Bloomberg's Jonathan Ferro, Annmarie Hordern and Lisa Abramowicz on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: How Elanco Plans on Winning in the Pet Wellness Boom
item.description: The animal health care company Elanco is reaffirming its second quarter and full year guidance. The company is also announcing a new CFO as the company looks to accelerate growth. Jeff Simmons, Elanco's CEO joined the C-Suite on Bloomberg's Open Interest to talk about the booming pet care market (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: In Rare Stab, Slovak Leader Tells Fico to Focus on the West
item.description: Slovakia’s president told Prime Minister Robert Fico to focus on maintaining the nation’s Western orientation in a rare rebuke of his ally’s policies.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

item.title: Doug Clinton: Nvidia Still On Top with "Using AI"
item.description: Doug Clinton, Intelligent Alpha CEO & Founder speaks Romaine Bostick about Nvidia earnings coming the next day and the AI arms race. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Chile Copper Miner Offers Chinese Smelters Negative Processing Fees as Talks Start
item.description: Chilean copper miner Antofagasta Plc has proposed negative treatment charges for sales to Chinese smelters amid a global squeeze on supplies of ore, according to people familiar with the negotiation.
item.dc:creator: Julian Luk, Winnie Zhu

media:content.media:description: The smelting area at a copper processing facility in Machali, Chile.

item.title: Dana Tesley: Consumers Are Still Spending
item.description: Dana Telsey, Telsey Advisory Group, Founder & CEO speaks with Romaine Bostick about retail earnings reporting this week and US consumer confidence. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: JPMorgan's Tredway: Home Affordability is Difficult
item.description: Chad Tredway, JPMorgan Asset Management, Global Head of Real Estate speaks with Alix Steel and Romaine Bostick about the outlook for commercial real estate. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Wall Street Giant Posts Record-Breaking Revenue
item.description: Citadel Securities is reporting record profit and trading revenue in the first three months of the year, with $3.4 billion in net trading revenue and $1.7 billion in net income. Bloomberg's Katherine Doherty joined Wall Street Beat on Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about what was behind the blow-out quarter. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Private Credit Bets Build at $46 Billion Money Manager Patria
item.description: Patria Investments Ltd., one of Latin America’s largest alternative asset managers, is accelerating its push into private credit.
item.dc:creator: Vinicius Andrade, Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo

media:content.media:description: Javier Montero, portfolio manager for Moneda Asset Management, stands for a photograph following an interview in Santiago, Chile, on Thursday, April 6, 2017. Montero sees an opportunity in the historic levels of depreciation Latin American currencies suffered since May 2013, with the tender of Chile, Brazil, Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela all dropping more than 25 percent, while Argentina's peso tumbled 66 percent. Photographer: Cristobal Palma/Bloomberg

item.title: Europe’s Skies Busier Than Before Covid in Boon for Fuel Demand
item.description: Europe’s skies are busier than before the Covid pandemic, a boon for the region’s fuel-supplying oil refiners.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels

media:content.media:description: A ground crew worker removes a fuel pipe from passenger aircraft on the tarmac at Vienna International Airport.

item.title: US Treasuries Slip Ahead of Auction With Spotlight on Demand
item.description: US Treasuries edged lower and were on track to snap three days of gains on Wednesday, as attention turns to a fresh wave of supply after recent auctions signaled weaker demand for government paper.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Ye Xie

item.title: Dubai Ruler’s Residential REIT Surges After $584 Million IPO
item.description: Dubai Holding’s $584 million residential real estate investment trust surged in its trading debut, as the city’s property market boom continues to lure investors.
item.dc:creator: Laura Gardner Cuesta

item.title: London Looks Past the Fast Fashion IPO That Divided the City
item.description: With Shein Group Ltd. turning its attention to Hong Kong for its initial public offering, London’s financial community is looking beyond the fast-fashion group as listing activity begins to break a years-long drought.
item.dc:creator: Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro, Joe Easton

media:content.media:description: A Shein Group Ltd. pop-up store.
